  • Action C is best when the five-sided shapes are most common. If the five-sided shapes are more common than the six- or seven-sided shapes, choosing Action A will earn you $1, choosing Action B will earn you $1, and choosing Action C will earn you $3.

  • Action B is best when the seven-sided shapes are most common. If the seven-sided shapes are more common than the five- or six-sided shapes, choosing Action A will earn you $0, choosing Action B will earn you $6, and choosing Action C will earn you $3.

9:
Reward

By completing the experiment you will receive a participation fee of 5 cents. You will also be rewarded based on the actions you choose in the {{rounds}} rounds. At the end of the experiment one of the rounds will be selected for final payment. Your reward will be determined by the action you have chosen in the selected round and which of the {{m}} shapes, {{true_polygons_text}} was most common in that round.

Each of the {{rounds}} rounds has a certain probability of being selected for final payment. These probabilities can be 0%, 1%, 2%, 4%, 8%, 16%, 32% and only one of the rounds will be selected for final payment at the end of the experiment. The number of rounds with a given probability of being selected are shown in the table below. Note that across the {{rounds}} rounds the probabilities add up to 100%. You will always be shown the probability of the current round being selected for final payment while you are completing the task. The order of these probabilities will be random.
10: Note, that if you just click through all the rounds without exerting any effort you might still select the best action in some rounds just by chance. This means that by chance you would select the best action in roughly 7 of the {{rounds}} rounds. Unfortunately, this behavior is not useful for us, so we will only reward you if your performance is above chance and you choose the best action 10 or more of {{rounds}} rounds.
11:
Selection of a Round for Final Payment:

To determine which round is selected for final payment we will let you stop the clock below. This is your computer clock, presenting the time down to the millisecond (1/1000th of a second).

Suppose the first round has 32% probability of being selected, and the second round has 8% probability. Then if the last two digits of the stopped millisecond timer is between 1 and 32, the first round gets selected, if it is between 33 and 40 the second round gets selected and so on.

Now, try to stop the clock showing the current time to millisecond precision. You should know that it is impossible for you to control these last two digits of the millisecond clock because of the time it takes the human brain and hand to respond. The purpose of this is to generate a random number, and match the probability of a round being selected for final payment. To confirm this randomness, you can start and stop the clock as many times as you want, to check if you can stop it at a number of your choice. Please stop the clock at least 3 times.
